title: 107_s2557
content: The Act titled "Medicare Improvements for Special Needs Beneficiaries Act of 2002" establishes specialized Medicare+Choice plans for special needs beneficiaries. The Medicare Improvements for Special Needs Beneficiaries Act of 2002 establishes specialized Medicare+Choice plans for special needs beneficiaries, allowing any type of coordinated care plan for this group. The term "specialized Medicare+Choice plan for special needs beneficiaries" is defined within the Act. The Medicare+Choice plan for special needs beneficiaries exclusively serves individuals with severe and disabling chronic conditions, who are institutionalized, entitled to medical assistance under a State plan, or meet other requirements set by the Secretary. The Medicare+Choice plan for special needs beneficiaries may restrict enrollment to individuals within specific classes of special needs beneficiaries, as defined by regulations of the Secretary, for periods before January 1, 2008. The Medicare+Choice plan for special needs beneficiaries must meet additional requirements, including establishing a clinical delivery system tailored to the needs of special needs beneficiaries. The Medicare+Choice plan for special needs beneficiaries must establish a clinical delivery system that includes patient assessment, chronic condition management, and care protocols. The Medicare+Choice plan for special needs beneficiaries must identify factors that increase the cost of care, such as specially trained healthcare staff and methods for integrating care across settings. Data collection and outcome measures development are also essential components. The organization offering the specialized Medicare+Choice plan for special needs beneficiaries must collect specified data to monitor the quality of healthcare services provided, including functional and diagnostic information. They must also maintain records and provide access to the Secretary. The organization offering a specialized Medicare+Choice plan for special needs beneficiaries must provide access to records, including financial, medical, and personnel records, and reports necessary for monitoring the plan's operation, cost, and effectiveness. They must also cooperate with the Secretary in developing health status and quality outcome measures. The specialized Medicare+Choice plan for special needs beneficiaries must have quality assurance measures in place, including a written plan and oversight by the Secretary to ensure effectiveness. The amendments made by subsection (a) shall take effect upon the date of enactment of this Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services shall issue final regulations to establish requirements for special needs beneficiaries by October 1, 2003. GAO will report to Congress on specialized Medicare+Choice plans for special needs beneficiaries. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress by December 31, 2006, assessing the impact of specialized Medicare+Choice plans for special needs beneficiaries on cost and quality of services. The report will include a general assessment of these plans, demographics and health status of beneficiaries, clinical models of care, and performance related to quality indicators determined by the Secretary. The report to Congress by the Comptroller General of the United States will assess specialized Medicare+Choice plans for special needs beneficiaries, including demographics, clinical models of care, and performance on quality indicators determined by the Secretary. It will also evaluate marketing materials, integration of care, financing, and administrative functions, as well as costs and savings to the Medicare program.
